image.altText: For Sale signage outside a suburban house.

items.synopsis: After a brief downturn earlier in the year, Australia's housing market is firmly in recovery mode, with CoreLogic data showing house prices increased for a sixth consecutive month in August.

image.altText: Two men with greying hair in suits shake hands on a street watched by other people

image.altText: People on a street hold up signs protesting against the release of wastewater from the Fukushima nuclear plant.

title.children: Japan started releasing treated nuclear wastewater from Fukushima into the Pacific. Reaction in China was swift

image.altText: A person holds a Voice to Parliament official referendum booklet

image.altText: Jetstar and Qantas planes next to each other on the tarmac at an airport.

items.synopsis: Qantas boss Alan Joyce has confirmed the airline and its subsidiary Jeststar have about $570 million in unclaimed credits. Here's how to figure out if you're owed a refund or how to redeem your credits.

title.children: Qantas and Jetstar are holding almost half a billion dollars in flight credits. Here's how to figure out what you're owed

image.altText: Close up of Qantas chief executive Alan Joyce speaking to the media at a press event.

items.synopsis: Qantas has confirmed it will refund $570 million worth of COVID travel credits for domestic and international customers, while the ACCC has accused the airline of selling tickets for flights it had already cancelled.

title.children: 'People lost faith in the process': Qantas scraps expiry dates on $570m worth of COVID travel credits

image.altText: A baby and a young woman in a car. Both have their faces blurred.

items.synopsis: As Crystal waited, along with thousands of others, for public housing in Western Australia, her 10-month-old son Kenneth died. Advocates say her story is becoming increasingly common.

title.children: Crystal has finally been offered a place to live, but it came too late for her baby son

image.altText: A woman in pink shirt standing in city street.

items.synopsis: Young culturally diverse Australians continue to face discrimination when trying to find work, according to recent studies. Experts found non-Anglo Australians struggle to get a job interview, despite being well qualified, and some are altering their identities on paper to get a fair go.

title.children: If you're a graduate with an English-sounding name, you may be closer to securing a job than some of your peers

image.altText: An Australian tennis player's arm muscles strain as he hits a backhand return during a match.

items.synopsis: Australian tennis star Alex de Minaur needs less than 90 minutes to storm into the US Open third round with a straight-sets win over China's Yibing Wu.

title.children: In-form de Minaur storms into round of 32 at US Open

image.altText: Australiam Army soldiers stand at attention during an Anzac Day parade

items.synopsis: AEMO's latest 10-year outlook is double-edged, foreshadowing both increased opportunities for generators and increased risks in terms of reliability — some sooner than others.

title.children: A cloud's just passed in front of Australia's electricity forecast — here's what it could mean

image.altText: A close up street view of an old Japanese house next to an apartment building.

items.synopsis: How does Tokyo's property market compare to Australia's? Here are four unique lessons, from loose zoning laws to smaller dwelling sizes, an advanced public transport system and an openness to development.

title.children: The four unique ways Tokyo approaches housing can offer lessons for Australia

image.altText: Boy with cuts on his face and bruising on his eyes

items.synopsis: An investigation is underway after a six-year-old boy was allegedly bitten by a support dog at his South Coast school, with reports he was attempting to give the labradoodle a cuddle.

title.children: Year 1 student recovering after support dog allegedly bites his face at school

image.altText: An illustration of a person's hand placing a ballot paper into a ballot box held by someone else's outstretched hands.

items.synopsis: For hundreds of thousands of Australians voting in the referendum on a Voice to Parliament, their votes will count differently to others. Here's why.

title.children: How some votes will be worth less than others in the upcoming referendum

image.altText: A mushroom with a split down the centre popping up through the gravel cement

items.synopsis: A photography exhibition in Manjimup, Western Australia, helps highlight the ecological importance of what some say is a forgotten part of the planet's biodiversity.

title.children: This award-winning photo isn't of a dragon's eye — it's a fungus growing through concrete

image.altText: A man with tattoos and sunglasses speaks into a microphone; Mitch Mcconnell stares at something offscreen

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Ex-Proud Boys leader gets 17 years over Capitol Riot, doctor says Mitch McConnell 'medically clear'. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ukraine has told critics of the pace of its three-month-old counteroffensive to "shut up". It's the sharpest signal yet of Kyiv's frustration at leaks from Western officials who say its forces are advancing too slowly. Since launching a much vaunted counteroffensive using many billions of dollars of Western military equipment, Ukraine has recaptured more than a dozen villages but has yet to penetrate Russia's main defences. Ukrainian commanders say they are moving slowly on purpose, degrading Russia's defences and logistics to reduce losses when they finally attack at full strength. Ukraine's Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba told reporters criticising the counter-offensive's pace equalled "spitting into the face of [the] Ukrainian soldier who sacrifices his life every day". "I would recommend all critics to shut up, come to Ukraine and try to liberate one square centimetre by themselves," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ukraine's Foreign Minister tells critics: 'Shut up'

children.content: Ukraine has told critics of the pace of its three-month-old counteroffensive to "shut up".
It's the sharpest signal yet of Kyiv's frustration at leaks from Western officials who say its forces are advancing too slowly.

Since launching a much vaunted counteroffensive using many billions of dollars of Western military equipment, Ukraine has recaptured more than a dozen villages but has yet to penetrate Russia's main defences.
Ukrainian commanders say they are moving slowly on purpose, degrading Russia's defences and logistics to reduce losses when they finally attack at full strength.
Ukraine's Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba told reporters criticising the counter-offensive's pace equalled "spitting into the face of [the] Ukrainian soldier who sacrifices his life every day".

props.alt: Ukraine's Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba speaks to the media

children.content: Dmytro Kuleba.
(Reuters: Isabel Infantes )
"I would recommend all critics to shut up, come to Ukraine and try to liberate one square centimetre by themselves," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Idalia has weakened further into a post tropical storm as it moved away from the US coast, according to the US National Hurricane Center. It has issued a tropical storm watch for Bermuda. The storm was about 265km south-east of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina, packing maximum sustained winds of 100kph, the NHC said. Meanwhile, in Florida the clean-up effort from the hurricane is underway, with photos showing the impact it has had.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Idalia weakens, clean-up effort begins in Florida

children.content: Idalia has weakened further into a post tropical storm as it moved away from the US coast, according to the US National Hurricane Center.
It has issued a tropical storm watch for Bermuda.
The storm was about 265km south-east of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina, packing maximum sustained winds of 100kph, the NHC said.
Meanwhile, in Florida the clean-up effort from the hurricane is underway, with photos showing the impact it has had.
A damaged property in Horseshoe Beach, Florida.
(Reuters: Julio Cesar Chavez)
A shrimp business destroyed by Hurricane Idalia in Horseshoe Beach.
(Reuters: Julio Cesar Chavez)
A damaged property after the arrival of Hurricane Idalia in Horseshoe Beach.
(Reuters: Julio Cesar Chavez)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal government says it's confident changes to prescription rules won't adversely affect pharmacies. From today, doctors can provide patients with 60-day prescriptions for a range of medicines used to treat chronic health conditions. The government argues it'll save patients money, but the Pharmacy Guild has warned it will threaten the viability of some community pharmacies. Health Minister Mark Butler told Nine: "We've received twice as many applications to open new pharmacies as we received at the same time last year, or the year before. "Clearly people out there think there is still money to be made running a pharmacy, and I'm confident there is too."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Twice as many' applications for pharmacies  amid new rules

children.content: The federal government says it's confident changes to prescription rules won't adversely affect pharmacies.
From today, doctors can provide patients with 60-day prescriptions for a range of medicines used to treat chronic health conditions.

Health Minister Mark Butler told Nine: "We've received twice as many applications to open new pharmacies as we received at the same time last year, or the year before.
"Clearly people out there think there is still money to be made running a pharmacy, and I'm confident there is too."
